chunks.text:
[Construction and Engineering > Site Selection]
Choose building sites on high ground with good drainage  never in a flood plain or dry riverbed. Face openings away from prevailing wind (typically away from southwest in the UK/Europe). Avoid hilltops (wind exposure) and valley floors (cold air pooling, flooding). Proximity to water is important but maintain at least 30m distance to avoid flooding and insect problems.

Check for overhead hazards: dead trees (widowmakers), unstable slopes, rockfall zones. In earthquake-prone areas, avoid building against steep slopes or cliff faces.

South-facing slopes (Northern Hemisphere) receive more sunlight  warmer in winter, better for growing food.

[Construction and Engineering > Basic Tools]
Essential construction tools in priority order: axe (felling, splitting, shaping), saw (crosscut or bow saw), knife (carving, detail work), shovel (earthworks), hammer (driving stakes and pegs), measuring tool (knotted cord or marked stick), level (water in a clear tube, or a plumb line), square (3-4-5 triangle for right angles).

The 3-4-5 method for right angles: measure 3 units along one edge, 4 units along the other, and the diagonal between them should be exactly 5 units. Works at any scale  3 metres, 4 metres, 5 metres for buildings.

[Construction and Engineering > Timber]
Green (freshly cut) timber is easier to work but shrinks as it dries, loosening joints. Seasoned (air-dried) timber is more stable. Air-drying takes 1 year per inch of thickness. Stack timber off the ground with spacers between layers for airflow, under cover.

Softwoods (pine, spruce, cedar) are easier to work and good for framing. Hardwoods (oak, ash, beech) are stronger and more durable  use for load-bearing members and tool handles.

Timber joints without nails: mortise and tenon (rectangular peg into rectangular hole), dovetail (interlocking wedge shape), lap joint (overlapping halves notched to sit flush), pegged joints (drill holes through joined pieces and insert wooden pegs).

[Construction and Engineering > Post and Beam Construction]
The simplest permanent structure. Vertical posts set into the ground or onto stone pads, horizontal beams across the top, rafters for the roof. For ground-set posts, bury at least 1/3 of the post length. Char the buried end with fire to resist rot (charring creates a carbon layer that repels water and insects).

For a basic rectangular building: 4 corner posts, horizontal wall plates along the top of each wall, tie beams across the width, rafters from ridge to wall plate. Add intermediate posts every 1.52m for walls. Fill walls with wattle and daub, cob, or stacked logs.

[Construction and Engineering > Wall Materials]
Wattle and daub: weave flexible branches (hazel, willow) between upright stakes to form wattle panels. Coat both sides with daub  a mixture of clay, straw/grass, sand, and water (optionally animal dung for binding). Apply in layers, letting each dry. Insulates reasonably well and lasts decades if kept dry above and below (roof overhang and raised foundation). Cob: a mixture of clay subsoil, straw, water, and sometimes sand. Mixed by treading and stacked in layers approximately 30cm high. Each layer must partially dry before adding the next. Walls are typically 4060cm thick. Excellent thermal mass  warm in winter, cool in summer. Needs a good roof overhang and a stone foundation to prevent rising damp. Log construction: horizontally stacked logs, notched at the corners. Saddle notch or Scandinavian cope for weather resistance. Gaps chinked with moss, clay, or a lime/sand mix. Requires straight, uniform-diameter logs  pine and spruce are ideal. Stone: dry stone walls (no mortar) for fences and low structures. For load-bearing walls, use mortar  lime morite is made by burning limestone (calcium carbonate) to make quicklime (calcium oxide), slaking with water to make hydrated lime, then mixing with sand. Ratio approximately 1 part lime to 3

[Construction and Engineering > Wall Materials]
low structures. For load-bearing walls, use mortar  lime morite is made by burning limestone (calcium carbonate) to make quicklime (calcium oxide), slaking with water to make hydrated lime, then mixing with sand. Ratio approximately 1 part lime to 3 parts sand. Lime mortar is flexible and breathable  superior to cement for traditional buildings. Adobe/mud brick: mix clay soil with straw and water, press into moulds, dry in the sun for 24 weeks. Stack with mud mortar. Works best in dry climates. Walls must be protected from rain with render or wide roof overhang.

[Construction and Engineering > Roofing]
A roof must shed water reliably  this is the most critical element of any building. Minimum pitch for thatch: 45. For shingles: 30. For corrugated metal: 15.

Thatch: bundles of reed, straw, or long grass, layered from eaves to ridge, each layer overlapping the one below. A well-made thatch roof lasts 1530 years. Thickness should be at least 30cm. Use hazel or willow spars (U-shaped pins) to secure bundles.

Wooden shingles (shakes): split thin from straight-grained logs (cedar, oak, chestnut). Overlap each course by at least 2/3. Nail or peg to battens on rafters.

Sod/turf roof: over a waterproof layer (birch bark, plastic sheeting, or dense clay), lay turf grass-side up. Heavy  structure must be built to support the weight. Good insulation. Traditional in Scandinavia.

[Construction and Engineering > Foundations]
All permanent structures need a foundation to distribute weight and prevent settling. At minimum, clear the topsoil and compact the subsoil. In cold climates, foundations must extend below the frost line (60120cm in temperate regions) to prevent frost heave.

Stone pad foundations: flat stones under each post. Simple and effective for light structures.

Continuous stone foundation: a trench filled with compacted rubble and topped with flat stones. Raises the building above ground moisture.

[Construction and Engineering > Earthworks]
Drainage ditches: dig a V-shaped trench uphill of your building to divert surface water. Minimum 30cm deep, angled to drain away from the structure. French drain: a gravel-filled trench that allows water to percolate through.

Rammed earth: build a form (two parallel boards held apart by spacers), fill with slightly damp earth (ideally 70% sand/gravel, 30% clay), and compact in 1015cm layers with a heavy rammer. Remove the form when complete. Extremely strong and durable. Walls are typically 3045cm thick. Used for thousands of years  some rammed earth walls survive from the Roman era.

[Construction and Engineering > Water Supply]
Gravity-fed water: if a water source is uphill of your settlement, you can pipe water downhill using any sealed pipe or tube. For every 10m of horizontal distance, you need at least 1m of vertical drop for adequate flow. Bamboo, hollowed logs, or salvaged plastic pipe all work.

Rainwater collection: 1mm of rain on 1 square metre of roof yields 1 litre of water. A 50 square metre roof in an area with 800mm annual rainfall collects 40,000 litres per year. Store in covered tanks or cisterns. First-flush diverters (discard the first few litres of each rain event) improve water quality.

Wells: dig by hand in areas with a high water table. Line with stone, brick, or timber to prevent collapse. Cover to prevent contamination. A hand pump can lift water from up to 7m depth with a suction pump, or deeper with a force pump.

[Construction and Engineering > Sanitation Infrastructure]
Latrines must be at least 30m from any water source and downhill/downstream. Dig at least 1.5m deep. A simple pit latrine with a raised seat and a ventilation pipe (VIP latrine) controls flies and odour. When 2/3 full, cover with 30cm of soil and dig a new one.

Long-term: composting toilet separates liquid and solid waste. Solid waste is mixed with carbon material (sawdust, dry leaves) and composted for 12+ months at high temperature before use on non-food crops.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Electrical Fundamentals]
Voltage (V) is electrical pressure  the force pushing electrons through a circuit. Current (A, amps) is the flow rate of electrons. Resistance (ohms) opposes current flow. Ohm's Law: V = I  R. Power (W, watts) = V  I.

A circuit must form a complete loop  current flows from the positive terminal of a power source, through the load (device), and back to the negative terminal. A break anywhere in the loop stops current flow (this is how a switch works).

Series circuits: components connected end-to-end. Current is the same through all components. Voltages add up. If one component fails, the whole circuit stops.

Parallel circuits: components connected side-by-side. Voltage is the same across all components. Currents add up. If one component fails, others continue working.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Batteries]
A battery converts chemical energy to electrical energy. Cells produce approximately 1.5V (alkaline) or 3.7V (lithium). Connect in series for higher voltage, in parallel for more capacity.

Car batteries (lead-acid): 12V, typically 40100 Ah (amp-hours). Rechargeable. Heavy but widely available and robust. Deep-cycle variants (marine/leisure batteries) tolerate repeated discharge better than starter batteries. Do not discharge below 50% to preserve lifespan.

Lithium-ion: high energy density, lightweight. 3.7V per cell. Found in laptops, power tools, electric vehicles. Require a charge controller  overcharging or over-discharging causes fire or permanent damage. Do not puncture, crush, or expose to high heat.

Battery capacity is rated in amp-hours (Ah). A 100Ah battery can theoretically deliver 1A for 100 hours, or 10A for 10 hours. Real capacity decreases at higher discharge rates and in cold temperatures.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Improvised Batteries]
Voltaic pile: stack alternating discs of copper and zinc (or two different metals) separated by cloth soaked in saltwater or vinegar (electrolyte). Each cell produces approximately 0.7V. Stack 20+ for a usable voltage.

Earth battery: bury two different metal rods (copper and zinc, or copper and iron) in moist earth, 1m apart. Produces 0.51V. Very low current but can trickle-charge small devices or power a crystal radio.

Lemon/potato battery: insert a copper wire and a zinc-coated nail into a lemon or potato. Each cell produces approximately 0.9V. Connect several in series for usable voltage.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Solar Power]
Photovoltaic (PV) panels convert sunlight directly to electricity. A typical panel produces 12V or 24V DC. Output depends on sunlight intensity  rated wattage is at peak sun (1000 W/m irradiance). In the UK, expect 24 peak sun hours per day on average annually.

A basic off-grid solar system: solar panel(s)  charge controller  battery bank  inverter (if AC power needed)  loads.

Charge controller: prevents battery overcharging and over-discharging. MPPT (Maximum Power Point Tracking) controllers are 1530% more efficient than PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) controllers. Worth the extra cost.

Sizing: determine your daily power consumption in watt-hours. A 100W panel in the UK with 3 peak sun hours produces approximately 300Wh per day. Add 25% for system losses. Battery bank should store at least 2 days of consumption.

Panel mounting: face south (Northern Hemisphere) at an angle equal to your latitude for year-round average. Steeper in winter, flatter in summer. Keep panels clean and unshaded  even partial shading drastically reduces output.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Wind Power]
Small wind turbines can supplement solar, especially in winter when solar output is low. Wind power is proportional to the cube of wind speed  doubling wind speed gives 8 more power. This means site selection is critical.

Minimum average wind speed for viable small wind: 5 m/s (11 mph). Mount the turbine as high as possible  wind speed increases with height. At least 10m above any obstacle within 150m.

A basic wind turbine: blades (carved from wood or cut from PVC pipe), a generator/alternator (salvaged car alternator, DC motor, or purpose-built), a tail vane for orientation, and a tower or pole mount. Output is wild AC  rectify to DC for battery charging.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Hydroelectric Power]
Moving water is the most consistent renewable energy source. Even a small stream with 2m of head (vertical drop) can generate useful power continuously.

Micro-hydro: divert water through a pipe (penstock) to a turbine at a lower point. Power = head (m)  flow rate (litres/sec)  7 (roughly, accounting for efficiency). So 5m head  10 L/s = 350W continuous  enough for lighting and small appliances for a settlement.

Overshot water wheel: water poured into buckets at the top of the wheel. The weight of water turns the wheel. Efficient (up to 85%) and works with moderate flow and head. Can be built from wood.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Generators]
Internal combustion generators convert fuel to electricity via an engine driving an alternator. Petrol generators are common but fuel is a finite resource. Diesel generators are more fuel-efficient. Both produce AC power.

Salvaging: any motor can be used as a generator when spun mechanically. DC motors produce DC. AC motors (induction type) require residual magnetism or external excitation to generate  a capacitor across the windings can self-excite an induction motor.

Bicycle generator: connect a bicycle to a generator via chain, belt, or friction drive. A fit person can sustain 75100W for extended periods. Enough to charge batteries, run lights, or power a radio.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Wiring and Safety]
Wire gauge matters: thicker wire carries more current with less loss. For 12V DC systems, voltage drop is significant over distance  use the thickest wire practical. As a rule: for 12V, keep wire runs short (under 5m) or use heavy gauge.

Fuses and circuit breakers protect against fire from short circuits or overloaded wires. A fuse is a thin wire that melts and breaks the circuit when current exceeds its rating. Always fuse the positive wire, as close to the battery as possible.

Grounding: connect the negative terminal of your system to a copper rod driven into the earth. This provides a safety path for fault currents and protects against lightning.

DC vs AC: batteries produce DC (direct current). Solar panels produce DC. Most electronics run on DC. AC (alternating current) is used for transmission over distance because transformers can step voltage up and down easily. An inverter converts DC to AC.

12V DC is safe to touch  below the threshold for dangerous current flow through skin. 240V AC (UK mains) or 120V AC (US mains) is lethal. Treat all AC systems with extreme caution.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Energy Storage and Conservation]
Energy conservation is easier than energy production. LED lighting uses 1/10th the power of incandescent bulbs. Insulate buildings to reduce heating energy. Use thermal mass (stone, water, earth) to store heat.

Thermal storage: heat water with solar collectors (even a black-painted tank in sunlight) and use it for heating and washing. A well-insulated water tank retains heat for days.

Flywheel storage: a heavy spinning wheel stores kinetic energy. Traditional potter's wheels and industrial flywheels use this principle. Can smooth out intermittent power from wind or human-powered generators.

[Electricity and Power Generation > Practical Low-Power Devices]
LED lighting: a single 1W LED produces useful light. Run directly from a 12V battery with a resistor, or use a 12V LED strip. A 100Ah battery can run a 1W LED for over 1000 hours.

Radio: a basic receiver draws 50200mW. A transceiver draws 15W on receive and 550W on transmit.

Raspberry Pi (computing): 515W depending on load. The Pip-Boy's Pi 5 draws approximately 8W average  a 100Ah 12V battery (1200Wh) could run it for 150 hours with a DC-DC converter.

Charging phones/devices: most phones charge at 5V, 12A (510W). A small solar panel (20W) can charge a phone in 23 hours of sun.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Soil Basics]
Healthy soil has: organic matter (5%+), good drainage, earthworms, a dark colour, and a crumbly texture. Clay soil holds water but drains poorly. Sandy soil drains fast but doesn't hold nutrients. Loam (mix of clay, sand, silt) is ideal.

Test soil pH with vinegar (fizzes = alkaline) and baking soda (fizzes = acidic). Most vegetables prefer pH 6.0-7.0. Add lime to raise pH, sulphur or pine needles to lower it.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Composting]
Mix "greens" (nitrogen-rich: food scraps, fresh grass, manure) with "browns" (carbon-rich: dry leaves, straw, cardboard) at roughly 1:3 ratio by volume. Turn the pile every 1-2 weeks. Keep moist but not wet. A well-managed compost pile reaches 55-65C (hot enough to kill weed seeds and pathogens). Ready in 2-6 months  finished compost is dark, crumbly, and smells earthy.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Crop Rotation]
Never plant the same family in the same bed two years in a row. Rotate in this order:
Year 1: Legumes (beans, peas)  fix nitrogen in soil.
Year 2: Brassicas (cabbage, broccoli, kale)  heavy feeders, use the nitrogen.
Year 3: Roots (carrots, potatoes, onions)  break up soil.
Year 4: Fruiting crops (tomatoes, squash, peppers)  light feeders.
Then back to legumes. This prevents disease buildup and maintains soil fertility.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Companion Planting]
Tomatoes + basil: basil repels aphids and whitefly. Also improves tomato flavour (anecdotal).
Carrots + onions: onion smell deters carrot fly, carrot smell deters onion fly.
Beans + sweetcorn + squash (Three Sisters): beans fix nitrogen, corn provides a climbing pole, squash shades the ground suppressing weeds.
Marigolds: plant throughout the garden  they repel nematodes and many insect pests.
Nasturtiums: act as a "trap crop"  aphids prefer them, keeping them off your vegetables.

Do NOT plant: tomatoes near potatoes (share blight), fennel near most vegetables (inhibits growth), beans near onions/garlic.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Seed Saving]
Open-pollinated varieties produce true-to-type seeds. Hybrid (F1) seeds do not  their offspring are unpredictable. For civilisation rebuilding, focus on heirloom/open-pollinated varieties.

Let the strongest, healthiest plants go to seed. Tomato seeds: scoop out seeds with pulp, ferment in water for 3 days (removes germination inhibitor), rinse, dry on paper. Bean/pea seeds: leave pods on the plant until they dry and rattle. Store all seeds in a cool, dry, dark place. Properly stored seeds remain viable for 2-10 years depending on species.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Basic Animal Husbandry]
Chickens: easiest livestock to start with. Provide eggs (1 per hen per day in peak season), meat, manure, and pest control. Need a secure coop (predator-proof), fresh water, feed (grain, scraps, bugs), grit for digestion, and calcium (crushed oyster shell) for strong eggshells. A rooster is needed for fertile eggs (breeding), not for egg production.

Goats: hardy, browse on weeds and scrub. Provide milk (dairy goats produce 2-4L/day), meat, and fibre (from certain breeds). Need fencing (goats escape everything), shelter, fresh water, and supplemental feed in winter.

Bees: provide honey (40-60 lbs per hive per year in good conditions), beeswax, and critical pollination services. A Langstroth hive is standard. Bees need a water source and diverse flowering plants within 5km.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Preserving the Harvest]
Canning: requires glass jars, lids, and a large pot for water bath (high-acid foods) or pressure canner (low-acid foods). Properly canned food lasts 1-5 years.

Drying: herbs, fruits, and vegetables can be sun-dried or dehydrator-dried. Store in airtight containers.

Fermentation: sauerkraut, kimchi, pickles. Uses salt and natural lactobacillus bacteria. No special equipment needed.

Root cellar: underground or earth-sheltered storage space maintaining 0-5C and high humidity. Stores potatoes, carrots, beets, apples, cabbage for months.

[Farming, Agriculture, and Animal Husbandry > Growing Calendar (Temperate Zone 7-8)]
March-April: sow peas, broad beans, lettuce, spinach, radishes outdoors. Start tomatoes, peppers, squash indoors.
May: plant out tomatoes, peppers after last frost. Direct sow beans, sweetcorn, courgettes.
June-July: harvest early crops, succession sow lettuce and beans.
August-September: sow overwintering crops (garlic, onion sets, winter lettuce, spring cabbage).
October-November: harvest root crops, clear beds, add compost, plant green manures (field beans, clover).

[Fire Making and Management > Fire Triangle]
Fire requires three elements: heat (ignition source), fuel, and oxygen. Remove any one and the fire goes out. Understanding this is the basis of both fire-starting and fire safety.

[Fire Making and Management > Fire Lay Preparation]
Gather materials BEFORE attempting ignition. You need three categories:
- Tinder: fine, dry, highly combustible material. Examples: dry grass, birch bark, cattail fluff, dryer lint, char cloth, fine wood shavings, dry pine needles, fatwood shavings. Must catch a spark or small flame easily.
- Kindling: small sticks and twigs, pencil-thickness or thinner. Must be dry  snap-test: dry wood snaps cleanly, wet wood bends.
- Fuel: larger pieces of wood from finger-thickness up to wrist-thickness. Build up gradually  don't smother the fire with large logs too early.

[Fire Making and Management > Fire Lay Types]
Teepee: arrange kindling in a cone shape over a tinder bundle. Good for a quick, hot fire. Collapses inward as it burns, feeding itself.

Log cabin: stack kindling in alternating layers like a log cabin, with tinder in the centre. Burns steadily and produces good coals.

Long fire: two parallel logs with fire between them. Good for cooking  pots rest on the logs. Also radiates heat along its length for sleeping beside.

Dakota fire hole: dig two holes 30cm apart, connected by a tunnel at the bottom. Build fire in one hole, the other serves as an air intake. Very efficient, low smoke, wind-resistant, and concealed. Excellent for cooking.

[Fire Making and Management > Ignition Methods]
Lighter or matches: most reliable. Keep in waterproof container. Ferro rod (ferrocerium): scrape with a steel striker or back of a knife. Produces sparks at 3000C. Works when wet. Direct sparks into tinder bundle. Flint and steel: strike carbon steel against flint, chert, or quartzite. Sparks land on char cloth or similar. Requires practice. Bow drill (friction): carve a fireboard (flat piece of dry softwood), a spindle (dry straight stick, ~2cm diameter, 30cm long), and a bearing block (hardwood or stone with a depression). Use a bow (curved stick with cordage) to spin the spindle against the fireboard. The friction creates a coal in the notch. Transfer the coal to a tinder bundle and blow gently. This works but requires practice and the right wood combination  willow on willow, poplar on poplar, or cedar on cedar are good pairings. Hand drill: similar to bow drill but you spin the spindle between your palms. More difficult and tiring. Use mullein, cattail, or yucca stalks as spindles. Fire piston: compresses air rapidly in a sealed cylinder, igniting tinder at the tip. Traditional tool in Southeast Asia. Magnifying lens: focus sunlight to a point on tinder. Any convex lens works  eyeglasses,

[Fire Making and Management > Ignition Methods]
cattail, or yucca stalks as spindles. Fire piston: compresses air rapidly in a sealed cylinder, igniting tinder at the tip. Traditional tool in Southeast Asia. Magnifying lens: focus sunlight to a point on tinder. Any convex lens works  eyeglasses, binocular lens, clear ice shaped into a lens, or a water-filled clear plastic bag curved to focus light.

[Fire Making and Management > Fire in Wet Conditions]
Split wet wood open  the inside is dry. Shave fine curls from the dry interior for tinder. Use standing deadwood rather than wood from the ground (ground wood absorbs moisture). Birch bark burns even when wet due to its oils. Pine resin (sap) is highly flammable. Look for fatwood (resin-saturated heartwood from dead pine trees)  it lights easily and burns hot.

Build a platform of sticks under your fire to keep it off wet ground. Start small and build up.

[Fire Making and Management > Fire Safety]
Clear a 3m circle around your fire down to mineral soil. Never leave a fire unattended. Keep water or soil nearby to extinguish. In windy conditions, use a Dakota fire hole or shield with rocks/logs. Don't build fires under overhanging branches, near dry grass, or near your shelter (sparks).

[Fire Making and Management > Char Cloth]
Cut cotton fabric into small squares, place in a sealed metal tin with a small hole in the lid. Put the tin in a fire. Smoke escapes through the hole. When smoke stops, remove from fire and seal the hole. The cloth inside is now charred  it catches sparks easily and holds an ember. Excellent tinder material.

[Fire Making and Management > Preserving Fire]
Carry an ember in a fire bundle: wrap a glowing coal in dry punk wood, bark, or moss. Wrap loosely so air can reach it but it won't blow out. A coal can last hours this way. Alternatively, use a slow match  a length of tightly twisted natural cordage that smoulders slowly.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Universal Edibility Test]
When unsure if a plant is safe to eat, use this systematic test. Only test ONE plant part at a time (leaf, stem, root, etc.).

1. Separate the plant into parts: leaves, stems, roots, buds, flowers.
2. Smell the part  reject anything that smells of almonds or peach (possible cyanide).
3. Rub a small piece on your inner wrist. Wait 15 minutes. If irritation occurs, reject.
4. Touch a small piece to the corner of your mouth. Wait 15 minutes.
5. Touch to your tongue. Wait 15 minutes.
6. Chew a small piece, hold in mouth for 15 minutes. Spit out.
7. If no ill effects, swallow a small amount. Wait 8 hours.
8. If no ill effects, eat a larger portion. Wait another 8 hours.
9. If still no ill effects, the plant part is likely safe to eat.

NEVER eat: mushrooms unless 100% positively identified. Do not use this test on mushrooms  some deadly mushrooms taste pleasant and symptoms appear days later.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Safe Common Wild Edibles (Temperate Regions)]
Dandelion: entire plant is edible. Leaves raw in salad or cooked (young leaves are less bitter). Roots can be roasted as coffee substitute. Flowers are edible. Nettles (stinging nettle): cook to neutralise stings. Rich in iron and vitamins. Boil or steam for 5 minutes. Young spring leaves are best. Makes excellent soup. Chickweed: small white-flowered ground cover. Mild flavour, eat raw or cooked. High in vitamins C and A. Clover (red and white): flowers and leaves are edible. Flowers are sweet. Dried flower heads can be ground into flour. Plantain (broadleaf): leaves are edible raw when young, or cooked when older. Seeds can be collected and ground. Blackberries/raspberries: obvious wild fruit. Leaves make a pleasant tea. Rose hips: the fruit of wild roses. Extremely high in vitamin C (20x more than oranges). Eat raw, make tea, or dry for storage. Remove seeds and hairs from inside. Acorns: from oak trees. Contain tannins that must be leached out. Shell, crush, and soak in multiple changes of water (or run water over them) until bitterness is gone. Then dry and grind into flour. Hawthorn: berries are edible raw or cooked. Leaves and flowers make tea. Berries can be made into jelly. Elder:

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Safe Common Wild Edibles (Temperate Regions)]
soak in multiple changes of water (or run water over them) until bitterness is gone. Then dry and grind into flour. Hawthorn: berries are edible raw or cooked. Leaves and flowers make tea. Berries can be made into jelly. Elder: flowers can be eaten or made into cordial. Berries MUST be cooked (raw elderberries cause nausea). Cook into jam, wine, or syrup. Do not eat leaves, bark, or stems  they contain cyanide.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Poisonous Plants to Avoid]
Foxglove (Digitalis): purple bell-shaped flowers. All parts are lethal  contains cardiac glycosides.
Hemlock (Conium): looks similar to wild carrot/parsley but has purple-blotched stems and a musty smell. Extremely toxic.
Deadly nightshade (Atropa belladonna): shiny black berries, all parts toxic.
Yew: red berries with a single seed. The seed and all green parts are lethal. The red berry flesh is technically not toxic but not worth the risk.
Lords-and-ladies (Arum maculatum): bright red berries, hooded flowers. All parts toxic.
Giant hogweed: causes severe burns on skin contact when exposed to sunlight. Do not touch.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Trapping and Hunting]
Snares: a loop of wire or strong cordage set on an animal trail. The animal walks through, the loop tightens around its neck or body. Set snares at ground level on rabbit runs (look for worn paths through undergrowth, droppings, fur on fences). Use 20-gauge brass wire or strong paracord. Set multiple snares  one in ten may produce a catch.

Deadfall trap: a heavy rock or log propped up by a trigger mechanism. When an animal takes the bait, the support collapses and the weight falls. Figure-4 trigger is the classic design: three sticks notched to interlock, with bait on the horizontal arm.

Fishing: improvise hooks from thorns, bones, safety pins, or bent wire. Use insects, worms, berries, or small pieces of bright cloth as bait. In still water, fish feed near shores at dawn and dusk. In streams, fish rest behind rocks facing upstream.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Food Preservation]
Drying/dehydrating: slice meat thinly, hang in sun or near a smoky fire. Jerky keeps for weeks. Dry fruit and herbs the same way.

Smoking: hot smoking cooks and preserves. Build a smoky fire (use green or damp wood for smoke) in a confined space with the food hung above. Smoke for 12-24 hours.

Salt curing: pack meat in salt. Salt draws out moisture and inhibits bacterial growth. Requires a lot of salt.

Fermentation: lacto-fermentation preserves vegetables. Pack shredded cabbage (or other vegetables) with 2% salt by weight into a jar, press down to submerge in its own liquid, cover, and leave at room temperature for 1-4 weeks. Creates sauerkraut  high in vitamins and probiotics.

Root cellaring: store root vegetables (potatoes, carrots, turnips) in a cool, dark, humid place (underground). They keep for months.

[Food Procurement, Foraging, and Preservation > Cooking Without Pots]
Hot rock cooking: heat rocks in a fire, then use them to boil water in a wooden bowl, animal skin, or bark container. Drop hot rocks in with wooden tongs, replace as they cool.

Spit roasting: skewer meat on a green (living) wood stick over coals.

Clay baking: wrap food (fish, roots, meat) in wet clay and place in hot coals. The clay hardens and steams the food inside. Peel off the clay when done.

Earth oven (hangi/imu): dig a pit, build a fire in it, heat rocks, rake out coals, place food wrapped in leaves on the rocks, cover with earth. Slow-cooks large quantities over several hours.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Why Governance Matters for Rebuilding]
After a collapse, the greatest threat is often not nature but other humans. Establishing fair governance early prevents warlordism, hoarding, and conflict. History shows that groups with agreed-upon rules and dispute resolution survive better than those without.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Foundational Principles]
Rule of law: laws apply equally to everyone, including leaders. No one is above the law.
Consent of the governed: authority derives from the people it serves. Leaders serve at the community's will.
Separation of powers: those who make rules, enforce rules, and judge disputes should be different people/groups. Concentration of all three in one person is tyranny.
Due process: no punishment without a fair hearing. The accused has the right to know the charges, present a defence, and be judged by impartial people.
Property rights: people must be secure in their possessions and the fruits of their labour, or they will not produce.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > The Magna Carta (1215)  Key Principles]
The Magna Carta established that even kings are subject to law. Key ideas still relevant:
- No free person shall be imprisoned, dispossessed, or destroyed except by lawful judgement of their peers or the law of the land. (Clause 39)
- Justice shall not be sold, denied, or delayed. (Clause 40)
- Taxes/levies require common consent. (Clause 12)
- Standardised weights and measures for fair trade. (Clause 35)

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Common Law Basics]
Common law developed in England over centuries. Core principles:
- Precedent: past decisions guide future ones. Consistency and predictability.
- Jury trial: judgement by ordinary community members, not just a single authority.
- Innocent until proven guilty: the burden of proof is on the accuser.
- Proportional punishment: the punishment should fit the crime.
- Right to self-defence: you may use reasonable force to protect yourself and others from imminent harm.
- Freedom of contract: people can make voluntary agreements that are binding.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Practical Small Community Governance]
For a post-collapse community of 20-200 people:

Council: elected representatives (one per ~20 people). Term limits (e.g., 1 year). Rotating leadership prevents power consolidation.

Community charter: a written document (constitution equivalent) that establishes:
- Rights: speech, property, fair trial, movement, association.
- Duties: contributing labour, militia/defence duty, following community decisions.
- Decision process: majority vote for ordinary matters, supermajority (2/3) for charter changes.
- Dispute resolution: mediation first, then arbitration by council.
- Expulsion: only for the most serious offences, by supermajority vote, after a hearing.

Resource management: common resources (water source, grazing land, forest) need explicit rules to prevent tragedy of the commons. Assign quotas, rotation schedules, or designate a steward.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Trade and Currency]
Barter works for small groups but becomes inefficient as communities grow. Historical solutions:
- Commodity money: a universally useful item becomes currency (salt, tobacco, ammunition, grain). Must be divisible, durable, portable, and have intrinsic value.
- Representative money: tokens (tally sticks, paper notes) that represent a claim on stored commodities.
- Key principle: the money supply should roughly match the goods available, or you get inflation (too much money) or deflation (too little).

Standardised weights and measures are critical for fair trade. Establish them early and enforce them.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Record Keeping]
Written records are civilisation's memory. Establish record-keeping for:
- Land boundaries and ownership
- Births, deaths, marriages
- Agreements and contracts
- Council decisions and laws
- Crop yields and resource inventories
- Technical knowledge (preserve this Pip-Boy's knowledge base in written form!)

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Conflict Resolution]
Escalation ladder:
1. Direct conversation between parties.
2. Mediation: a neutral third party helps them find agreement.
3. Arbitration: a neutral third party hears both sides and makes a binding decision.
4. Council hearing: for serious matters affecting the community.
5. Exile/separation: absolute last resort for irreconcilable dangerous individuals.

Violence as a resolution method should be explicitly prohibited by the community charter. Self-defence remains a right.

[Governance, Law, and Social Organisation > Defence and Security]
Organise a community militia: every able-bodied adult trains and takes shifts on watch. Establish a perimeter, communication signals, and a plan for various threats. Stockpile defensible positions. Intelligence: maintain awareness of other groups in the region  trade where possible, prepare for conflict where necessary.

[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Why History Matters for Survival]
Understanding why civilisations collapsed reveals patterns we can avoid. Nearly every collapse shares common causes: resource depletion, environmental degradation, inequality, loss of institutional knowledge, and failure to adapt. The solutions that rebuilt societies are equally instructive.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > The Bronze Age Collapse (c. 1200 BCE)]
One of the most catastrophic collapses in history. Within 50 years, nearly every major civilisation in the Eastern Mediterranean fell  the Hittites, Mycenaean Greeks, Egyptians (weakened), Ugarit, and others. International trade networks that had connected them all collapsed simultaneously.

Causes: a cascade of interconnected failures  drought and famine, earthquakes, disrupted trade routes, invasions by displaced peoples (the "Sea Peoples"), and systems too complex and interdependent to survive disruption of any single element.

Lesson: highly interconnected systems are fragile. When one node fails, cascading failures can bring down the entire network. Resilient systems need redundancy and the ability to function independently. A settlement should be able to survive isolation from external supply chains.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.id: history.txt:The Fall of Rome (476 CE, Western Empire):0
chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > The Fall of Rome (476 CE, Western Empire)]
The Roman Empire sustained 50+ million people across Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East through sophisticated infrastructure  roads, aqueducts, sanitation, law, and trade. The Western Empire declined over centuries before its formal end.

Causes: overextension of military and borders, economic inflation (debasing coinage), loss of tax base, reliance on mercenary armies with no loyalty to the state, lead in water systems contributing to health problems, political instability (26 emperors in 50 years during the Crisis of the Third Century), and pressure from migrating peoples.

Aftermath: the "Dark Ages" saw loss of literacy, engineering knowledge (concrete formula forgotten for centuries), long-distance trade, and urban living. Population in Rome fell from over 1 million to approximately 20,000. Aqueducts broke and no one could repair them. Roads deteriorated. Knowledge survived primarily in monasteries and the Eastern (Byzantine) Empire.

Lesson: institutional knowledge must be preserved and distributed, not concentrated. When the few people who know how something works die or leave, the capability is lost. Written records, apprenticeship, and redundancy of knowledge are essential. Also: maintaining infrastructure is cheaper than rebuilding from nothing.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse
chunks.section: The Fall of Rome (476 CE, Western Empire)

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > The Black Death (13471353)]
The bubonic plague killed 3060% of Europe's population within 6 years. Carried by fleas on rats, spread along trade routes.

Effects: labour shortages ended feudal serfdom (survivors could demand wages), fields lay fallow, villages were abandoned, social order fractured, religious authority was questioned. But the survivors inherited the resources of the dead  per capita wealth increased dramatically, leading to innovation, exploration, and eventually the Renaissance.

Lessons: epidemic disease is the fastest existential threat to a community. Quarantine works  the word comes from "quarantina," the 40-day isolation period Venice imposed on arriving ships. Sanitation and pest control are not luxuries. Communities that isolated early suffered least. Stockpile knowledge of herbal medicines and basic disease prevention. A small community with good hygiene practices can survive a pandemic that destroys larger, denser populations.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Easter Island (Rapa Nui) Collapse]
A Polynesian society on a remote Pacific island that deforested their entire island by approximately 1600 CE. Without trees: no canoes (ending deep-sea fishing), no fuel, catastrophic soil erosion destroying agriculture. Population crashed from perhaps 15,000 to approximately 2,000.

Lesson: environmental resources are finite. If consumption exceeds regeneration, collapse is inevitable. The islanders could see the last trees being cut  yet continued. A functioning governance system must enforce sustainable resource use even when short-term incentives favour exploitation.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > The Dust Bowl (1930s, USA)]
Industrial-scale ploughing of the Great Plains destroyed native grasslands whose root systems held the topsoil in place. Years of drought turned millions of acres to dust. Massive dust storms buried farms and towns. Hundreds of thousands of people displaced.

Lesson: soil is the foundation of civilisation and takes centuries to form. Protect it. Never strip vegetation from large areas. Practice conservation agriculture: minimal tillage, crop rotation, cover crops, windbreaks. See the Farming domain for soil management details.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Key Technologies That Rebuilt Societies]
Writing and record-keeping: every successful recovery from collapse was accompanied by the preservation or reinvention of writing. Written knowledge survives the death of individuals. Prioritise creating written records of all critical knowledge, procedures, and decisions.

The printing press: before Gutenberg (1440s), every book was copied by hand  knowledge was scarce and easily lost. Mechanical reproduction of text was the single most transformative technology for preserving and spreading knowledge. In a modern collapse scenario, the digital equivalent is creating multiple physical copies of essential knowledge.

Agriculture: the Neolithic revolution took millennia, but each subsequent recovery took less time because the knowledge of farming persisted. A community that can grow food is a community that survives.

Metallurgy: every historical civilisation required metal tools for advancement. See the Metalworking domain.

Rule of law: societies without agreed rules devolve into violence. See the Governance domain.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Patterns of Successful Recovery]
Communities that recovered fastest from collapse shared common traits:

1. Geographic advantage: access to fresh water, fertile soil, defensible position, and a temperate climate.

2. Preserved knowledge: whether through written records, oral tradition, or retained specialists. The monasteries of Ireland and Britain preserved classical knowledge through the Dark Ages. The Islamic Golden Age (8th14th centuries) preserved and expanded Greek, Roman, and Persian knowledge when Europe could not.

3. Trade networks: no community is fully self-sufficient long-term. Establishing trade for resources you lack (salt, metals, medicine, specialist skills) is essential. Trade also prevents conflict  people who trade with each other have economic incentive not to fight.

4. Social cohesion: communities with shared purpose, mutual trust, and fair governance survived. Those riven by faction, hoarding, and inequality collapsed further. See Governance domain.

5. Adaptability: rigid systems fail. Societies that changed farming practices, moved to new territory, adopted new technologies, or restructured governance when circumstances changed  those survived.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Preserving Knowledge]
The greatest risk in a collapse is not death from violence or starvation  it is the loss of knowledge. A single generation without transmission of critical skills (metalworking, medicine, engineering, agriculture, literacy) sets recovery back by centuries.

Practical steps: maintain a physical library of essential reference books. Write down procedures and techniques. Train multiple people in every critical skill  no single point of failure. Teach children to read and write  literacy is the foundation of all other knowledge preservation. Establish an apprenticeship system for practical skills.

Critical knowledge to preserve: agriculture and food preservation, water purification, basic medicine and surgery, metallurgy, construction, animal husbandry, navigation, mathematics (at least arithmetic, geometry, and basic algebra), basic chemistry, sanitation, and governance/law.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > Common Mistakes After Collapse]
Centralising all resources under one leader without accountability (leads to tyranny and resentment). Consuming seed stock for food (destroys future harvests). Failing to establish sanitation (epidemic disease). Conflict over resources instead of cooperation (weakens everyone). Ignoring long-term sustainability for short-term survival (the Easter Island trap). Abandoning record-keeping (knowledge loss). Failing to establish trade (isolation leads to deficiency and stagnation).
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse > The Long View]
Every collapse in history was eventually followed by recovery. The recovery was faster when knowledge was preserved, governance was fair, and communities cooperated. The goal of this knowledge base is to compress the recovery time  to skip the centuries of re-learning by preserving critical knowledge in a portable, searchable, always-available format. That is the purpose of the Pip-Boy.
chunks.domain: Historical Knowledge and Lessons from Collapse

chunks.text:
[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Rope Materials]
Natural fibre ropes: manila (strong, moderate stretch, degrades in UV/water), sisal (rough, cheap, weakens when wet), cotton (soft, weak, good for lashing padding), hemp (strong, durable, stiffens with age).

Synthetic ropes: nylon (strong, elastic, absorbs shock, weakens in UV over time), polyester (strong, low stretch, UV resistant, good for general use), polypropylene (floats, cheap, weakens in UV and heat), Dyneema/Spectra (extremely strong for its weight, low stretch, slippery  knots may slip).

Paracord (550 cord): nylon, 4mm diameter, rated to 250kg (550 lbs). Contains 7 inner strands that can be separated for lighter tasks (fishing line, sewing thread, snare line). The outer sheath is useful on its own. The most versatile cordage for survival  carry at least 30m.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Improvised Cordage]
Twist plant fibres into rope: harvest long fibres from inner bark (lime/linden, willow, elm), stinging nettles, cattail leaves, yucca, or long grass. Bundle fibres and twist tightly in one direction. Fold the bundle at the midpoint. The two halves will wrap around each other in the opposite direction (reverse twist or Z-twist). This makes a two-ply cord. Add new fibres by overlapping them 10cm before the current fibres run out. Two-ply cords can be twisted together to make thicker rope.

Rawhide: strips of animal hide, scraped and dried. Extremely strong when dry. Shrinks as it dries  useful for binding tool heads (the shrinkage tightens the binding). Weakens when wet.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Essential Knots]
Overhand knot: the simplest knot  a single loop pulled tight. Used as a stopper knot to prevent rope from pulling through a hole. Hard to untie after loading. Figure-eight knot: a better stopper knot. Form a loop, pass the end around behind the standing part, then through the loop. Easier to untie than an overhand after loading. Square knot (reef knot): joins two ropes of equal diameter. Left over right, then right over left (or vice versa  the key is alternating). Used for tying bandages and bundling. NOT reliable for joining ropes under heavy load  use a sheet bend instead. Sheet bend: joins two ropes, especially of different diameters. Form a bight in the thicker rope. Pass the thinner rope up through the bight, around behind both legs of the bight, and back under itself. For extra security, use a double sheet bend (wrap the thinner rope twice around the bight). Bowline: creates a fixed loop that does not slip or bind under load. Forms a rescue loop, tie-off point, or mooring. The rabbit comes out of the hole, goes around the tree, and back down the hole. Practice until you can tie it one-handed and in

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Essential Knots]
does not slip or bind under load. Forms a rescue loop, tie-off point, or mooring. The rabbit comes out of the hole, goes around the tree, and back down the hole. Practice until you can tie it one-handed and in the dark. The bowline is arguably the single most useful knot. Clove hitch: ties a rope to a post or pole. Two turns around the pole with the end tucked under the second turn. Quick to tie and untie. Can slip under heavy or varying loads  secure the free end with a half hitch. Taut-line hitch (adjustable grip hitch): an adjustable loop knot. Slides to tension or loosen but holds under load. Excellent for guy lines on tents and tarps. Trucker's hitch: a mechanical advantage system for tensioning rope. Creates a pulley effect in the rope itself, giving approximately 3:1 mechanical advantage. Tie a loop in the standing part (using an alpine butterfly or slip knot), pass the free end around the anchor and back through the loop, then pull. Secure with two half hitches. Essential for securing loads, tightening ridgelines, and building shelters. Prusik knot: a friction hitch that grips a rope when loaded but slides when unloaded.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Essential Knots]
end around the anchor and back through the loop, then pull. Secure with two half hitches. Essential for securing loads, tightening ridgelines, and building shelters. Prusik knot: a friction hitch that grips a rope when loaded but slides when unloaded. Wrap a loop of thinner cord around a thicker rope 3 times, then pass the loop through itself. Used for ascending ropes, adjustable tent guy lines, and rescue systems. The cord must be thinner than the rope it grips. Alpine butterfly: a fixed loop tied in the middle of a rope. Strong in all three directions (both ends and the loop). Useful for creating a tie-off point without access to either end of the rope. Also isolates a damaged section of rope. Constrictor knot: a binding knot that grips extremely tightly. Like a clove hitch but the end passes under the first turn as well. Once loaded, it's nearly impossible to untie  must be cut off. Excellent for binding bundles, closing bags, and temporary hose clamps.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Lashings]
Square lashing: joins two poles at right angles. Start with a clove hitch on the vertical pole below the horizontal. Wrap the rope around both poles in a square pattern (over the horizontal, behind the vertical, under the horizontal, in front of the vertical)  repeat 34 times. Then wrap between the poles (frapping turns) to tighten the whole lashing. Finish with a clove hitch. Used for building frames, shelters, bridges, and furniture. Diagonal lashing: joins two poles that cross but don't touch (eg. bracing in an X pattern). Start with a timber hitch around both poles. Wrap diagonally around both poles 34 times in one direction, then 34 times in the other direction (at 90 to the first wraps). Frap between the poles. Finish with a clove hitch. Shear lashing: joins two parallel poles (eg. for an A-frame). Clove hitch on one pole. Wrap around both poles 810 times, loosely. Frap between the poles 23 times. Clove hitch on the other pole. Spread the poles apart into an A-frame. Tripod lashing: like a shear lashing but with three poles. Lay three poles side by side. Clove hitch on an outer pole. Wrap all three 68 times (over and under,

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Lashings]
the other pole. Spread the poles apart into an A-frame. Tripod lashing: like a shear lashing but with three poles. Lay three poles side by side. Clove hitch on an outer pole. Wrap all three 68 times (over and under, weaving between them). Frap between each adjacent pair. Clove hitch on the other outer pole. Stand up and spread into a tripod.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Practical Applications]
Ridge line for shelter: tie a trucker's hitch or taut-line hitch between two trees at head height. Drape a tarp over it. Stake the corners with taut-line hitches on guy lines.

Lashed A-frame shelter: shear-lash two poles into a V, lash a ridge pole to the apex, lean branches against the ridge pole. Cover with tarp, leaves, or thatch.

Rope bridge (monkey bridge): tension a thick rope across a stream at foot level using trucker's hitches. Add two hand ropes at shoulder height. Lash vertical support poles at each end. Cross by walking on the foot rope while holding the hand ropes.

Ladder: lash rungs between two long poles using square lashings.

Drag stretcher: lash two long poles parallel with cross-members. Weave rope or fabric between them. For carrying an injured person.

Snares: a running loop (slip knot or Ackerman's loop) set on an animal trail. The animal pushes through and tightens the loop.

[Knots, Lashings, and Ropework > Rope Care]
Avoid stepping on rope  grit works into the fibres and causes internal abrasion. Store rope coiled and dry. Inspect for wear, fraying, or damage before critical use. Wet natural-fibre rope shrinks and stiffens  useful for tightening lashings but may weaken the rope.

Cut ends should be whipped (bound with thin cord) or melted (synthetic ropes) to prevent unravelling. To melt, briefly touch the end to a flame and press flat with a wet finger (carefully  molten nylon is hot).

[Medical and First Aid > Primary Assessment (DR ABC)]
D  Danger: ensure the scene is safe for you and the casualty.
R  Response: tap shoulders, shout "Are you okay?" Check for consciousness.
A  Airway: tilt head back, lift chin to open airway. Check for obstructions.
B  Breathing: look, listen, feel for 10 seconds. If not breathing, begin CPR.
C  Circulation: check for severe bleeding. Apply direct pressure to stop major haemorrhage.

[Medical and First Aid > CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation)]
For adults: 30 chest compressions at 100-120 per minute, 5-6cm deep, centre of chest. Then 2 rescue breaths. Repeat. Push hard and fast. If unwilling or unable to give breaths, compression-only CPR is still effective. Continue until help arrives or the person recovers.

For children (1-puberty): same ratio, 30:2, but use one hand for compressions, 5cm deep.
For infants (<1 year): 30:2 ratio, two fingers for compressions, 4cm deep. Cover mouth AND nose for breaths.

[Medical and First Aid > Bleeding Control]
Direct pressure: press firmly with a clean cloth, do not remove the cloth even if blood soaks through  add more layers. Elevate the limb above the heart if possible.

Tourniquet: for life-threatening limb bleeding that direct pressure cannot control. Apply 5-7cm above the wound (never on a joint). Tighten until bleeding stops. Note the time applied. A tourniquet should be a last resort  it can cause tissue damage if left on too long, but it saves lives. An improvised tourniquet: use a strip of fabric at least 4cm wide with a windlass (stick to twist and tighten). Never use wire, string, or narrow materials.

[Medical and First Aid > Wound Care]
Clean the wound with clean water  flush thoroughly to remove debris. If available, use dilute iodine or saline. Apply antibiotic ointment if available. Cover with a clean dressing and bandage. Change dressings daily. Watch for signs of infection: increasing redness, warmth, swelling, pus, red streaks from the wound, fever.

[Medical and First Aid > Burns]
Cool immediately with clean running water for 20 minutes. Do not use ice, butter, or toothpaste. Do not burst blisters  they protect the underlying skin. Cover with cling film or a clean non-fluffy dressing. Severe burns (larger than the casualty's palm, or on face/hands/genitals/joints) need professional care.

First degree: red, painful, no blisters (sunburn). Will heal on its own.
Second degree: blisters, very painful, red/white mottled skin. Risk of infection.
Third degree: white/charred, may be painless (nerve damage). Always needs medical care.

[Medical and First Aid > Fractures]
Signs: pain, swelling, deformity, inability to use the limb, grating sensation, bruising.

Immobilise the fracture: splint the limb in the position found. Use sticks, rolled newspaper, or any rigid material padded with cloth. Secure above and below the fracture site. Check circulation below the splint (pulse, colour, sensation) regularly.

Open fracture (bone through skin): do not push bone back in. Cover with a clean moist dressing, splint, and get to medical help urgently. High risk of infection.

[Medical and First Aid > Dislocations]
Do not attempt to relocate a dislocated joint unless trained. Immobilise in the position found. Apply ice if available to reduce swelling. A dislocated shoulder can sometimes be self-reduced using the Cunningham technique (massaging specific muscle groups) but this requires training.

[Medical and First Aid > Hypothermia]
Symptoms progress: shivering, confusion, slurred speech, drowsiness, loss of shivering (severe), unconsciousness.

Treatment: get to shelter, remove wet clothing, insulate from the ground, wrap in blankets/sleeping bags, provide warm sweet drinks if conscious. Skin-to-skin contact in a sleeping bag is effective. Do NOT rub extremities, apply direct heat to skin, or give alcohol. Rewarm gradually  rapid rewarming can cause cardiac arrest in severe cases.

[Medical and First Aid > Heat Illness]
Heat exhaustion: heavy sweating, weakness, nausea, headache, dizziness. Move to shade, cool with water, give fluids with electrolytes.

Heat stroke: body temperature above 40C, confusion, hot dry skin (sweating may stop), seizures. This is a medical emergency. Cool aggressively: immerse in cold water, apply ice to neck/armpits/groin. Call for help immediately.

[Medical and First Aid > Dehydration]
Signs: dark urine, dry mouth, headache, dizziness, rapid heartbeat, low urine output. Treat by drinking water with electrolytes. Oral rehydration solution: 1 litre water + 6 teaspoons sugar + half teaspoon salt.

[Medical and First Aid > Choking]
Adult: encourage coughing. If unable to cough: 5 back blows between shoulder blades, then 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich manoeuvre). Alternate until obstruction clears.

[Medical and First Aid > Anaphylaxis]
Severe allergic reaction: swelling of face/throat, difficulty breathing, rash, drop in blood pressure. Use an EpiPen (epinephrine auto-injector) if available  inject into outer thigh. Call for emergency help. Place casualty on their back with legs elevated (unless breathing difficulty, then sit them up).

[Medical and First Aid > Natural Remedies (Emergency Use)]
Honey: antibacterial properties, can be applied to wounds. Also effective for coughs.
Yarrow: crushed leaves applied to wounds help stop bleeding (traditional poultice).
Plantain (the weed, not the banana): chewed leaf applied as a poultice for insect stings and minor wounds.
Willow bark: contains salicin (aspirin precursor). Chew or make tea for pain relief and fever reduction.
Garlic: has antibacterial properties. Crushed and applied to wounds or eaten raw for respiratory infections.
Charcoal: activated charcoal can be used for poisoning (adsorbs toxins in the stomach). Do NOT use for corrosive substances.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Why Metalworking Matters]
The ability to work metal is one of the key differences between basic survival and rebuilding civilisation. Metal tools, fasteners, weapons, cooking implements, and hardware are essential for construction, agriculture, medicine, and defence. A functioning forge is one of the highest-priority infrastructure items for any permanent settlement.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Types of Metal]
Iron and steel: iron is smelted from iron ore (red/brown rocks, heavy for their size) or salvaged from existing structures (rebar, car parts, tools). Steel is iron with 0.22% carbon added. Low-carbon steel (mild steel) is easy to work and weld. High-carbon steel (0.61.4%) can be hardened and holds an edge  essential for tools and blades. Stainless steel contains chromium and is corrosion-resistant but harder to forge.

Copper: soft, easily worked, excellent conductor. Found in electrical wiring, plumbing, and electronics. Melts at 1085C  achievable in a charcoal forge with bellows.

Bronze: copper + tin alloy. Harder than copper. Historically used for tools, weapons, and bearings before iron became widespread. Melts at around 950C.

Aluminium: lightweight, corrosion-resistant. Melts at 660C  easy to melt and cast. Found in cans, engine parts, window frames. Cannot be forged effectively  casting is the primary method.

Lead: very soft, low melting point (327C). Can be melted over a campfire. Used for sinkers, bullets, pipe joints, and radiation shielding. Toxic  avoid skin contact and never heat in an enclosed space.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > The Forge]
A forge heats metal to working temperature. A basic forge needs: a fire container (firepot), fuel (charcoal or coal), an air supply (bellows or blower), and something to hold the work.

Simple forge construction: dig a shallow pit or build a clay/brick trough approximately 30cm wide, 30cm deep, 60cm long. Insert an air pipe (tuyere) through the side near the bottom  a steel pipe 23cm diameter works well. Connect to bellows or a hand-cranked blower. Fill with charcoal. Light the fire and pump air  the temperature will reach 11001300C, sufficient for forging steel.

Charcoal is the preferred fuel for a hand-built forge. It burns cleaner than coal, produces less sulphur (which weakens steel), and can be made from hardwood (see below). Coal works well but produces clinker (slag) that must be cleared from the firepot.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Making Charcoal]
Build a large fire of hardwood, then cover it with earth leaving a small chimney hole. The wood pyrolyses  volatile gases burn off while carbon remains. The process takes 1224 hours. When smoke turns from white/yellow to thin blue, the charcoal is ready. Seal all openings and let cool completely (24+ hours). Good charcoal is black, light, and rings when struck.

Alternatively: pack cut hardwood into a metal drum with a small hole in the lid. Place the drum in a fire. Gases escape through the hole and burn. When the flame from the hole turns blue and dies, the charcoal is ready. Seal the hole, remove from fire, and let cool.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > The Anvil]
An anvil provides a solid surface for hammering. A proper blacksmith's anvil has a flat face, a horn (pointed end) for bending curves, and a hardy hole for tooling. Weight matters  heavier anvils absorb more hammer force, making work easier.

Improvised anvils: a section of railway rail (set on end or on its side), a large sledgehammer head set in a stump, a thick piece of steel plate (25mm+) bolted to a heavy stump, or a large flat rock for basic cold-working.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Basic Forging Operations]
Drawing out: lengthening metal by hammering on the flat face. Work at bright orange-to-yellow heat (9001100C for steel). Hit square, then rotate 90 and hit again to maintain an even cross-section.

Upsetting: thickening metal by hitting on the end. Heat the section you want to thicken, hold vertically, and strike the top. Used to create heads on bolts, nails, and tools.

Bending: heat the section you want to bend. Use the anvil edge or horn. For tight bends, use a bending fork (two prongs mounted in the hardy hole).

Punching and drifting: punch a hole through hot metal using a punch (a pointed tool struck with a hammer). Widen and shape the hole with a drift (a tapered tool driven through the hole).

Forge welding: the oldest welding method. Heat two pieces of steel to white heat (1200C+), sprinkle flux (borax) on the joint to prevent oxidation, then hammer together firmly. The pieces fuse into a single piece. Requires practice and high temperatures.

Cutting: use a hot cut chisel (placed on the metal, struck with a hammer) to cut through hot steel on the anvil. Always use a sacrificial plate under the work to protect the anvil face.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Heat Treatment]
Hardening: heat high-carbon steel to bright cherry red (approximately 800C  it becomes non-magnetic at this temperature, test with a magnet). Quench rapidly in water (fastest, most brittle), oil (moderate), or brine (fastest, use with caution). The steel becomes very hard but also very brittle.

Tempering: after hardening, reheat to a lower temperature to reduce brittleness while retaining hardness. Watch the surface colour as it heats (clean the surface with sandpaper first): pale straw (220C) = maximum hardness, good for razors and scribes; dark straw (240C) = cutting tools, axes; brown (260C) = springs, punches; purple (280C) = cold chisels, axes; blue (300C) = springs, saws. Quench when the desired colour appears.

Annealing: heat to cherry red and cool very slowly (bury in dry ash or vermiculite). This makes steel as soft as possible  useful before filing, drilling, or machining.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Essential Items to Forge]
Nails: the most consumed fastener. Draw out a thin rod, cut lengths, upset one end for a head. A skilled blacksmith can produce hundreds per day.

Knives and blades: start with high-carbon steel (an old file, spring steel from a vehicle, or a saw blade). Forge to shape, grind the edge, heat treat (harden and temper).

Hinges, hooks, and hardware: simple bending and punching operations.

Agricultural tools: hoes, sickles, plough points, rake tines.

[Metalworking and Blacksmithing > Safety]
Always wear eye protection  scale (oxide flakes) flies off hot metal when struck. Leather apron protects from sparks and hot metal. Never forge galvanised steel  zinc fumes cause metal fume fever (flu-like symptoms, potentially fatal with heavy exposure). Remove galvanising by soaking in vinegar before forging, or grind it off.

Hot metal looks the same as cold metal in daylight once below about 400C  always assume metal near the forge is hot. Use tongs, not hands. Keep the forge area clear of flammable materials. Have water available for cooling and fire control.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Magnetic Compass]
A magnetic compass needle aligns with Earth's magnetic field. The red/marked end points to magnetic north. Magnetic north is NOT true north  the difference is called magnetic declination, which varies by location and changes over time. In the UK, declination is approximately 1 west (negligible). In parts of North America it can be 1020 east or west.

To take a bearing: point the direction-of-travel arrow at your target. Rotate the bezel until the orienting arrow aligns with the magnetic needle. Read the bearing at the index line. To follow a bearing: set the bearing on the bezel, hold the compass flat, rotate your body until the needle aligns with the orienting arrow, then walk in the direction the travel arrow points.

Compass errors: keep metal objects, electronics, and magnets away from the compass  they cause deviation. Large iron deposits in the ground can deflect the needle. Power lines and vehicles also cause interference.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Improvised Compass]
Magnetise a needle by stroking it in one direction (same direction, 50+ strokes) with a magnet, silk, or even your hair. Float it on a leaf on still water or suspend it from a thread. The magnetised end points roughly north-south. Determine which end is north by checking against the sun's position.

A razor blade rubbed on the palm of your hand 20+ times in one direction can also be magnetised enough to work as a crude compass when floated on water.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Map Reading]
Topographic maps show terrain using contour lines  lines connecting points of equal elevation. Closely spaced contour lines indicate steep terrain. Widely spaced lines indicate flat or gentle terrain.

Orient your map: align the map's north-south grid lines with your compass needle (accounting for declination). Your map is now oriented to the terrain.

Identify your position by triangulation: take bearings to two or three known landmarks. Draw the back-bearings on the map. Your position is where the lines intersect.

Grid references: most topographic maps use a grid system. A 6-figure grid reference identifies a 100m square. Read eastings (left to right) first, then northings (bottom to top). Remember: "along the corridor, then up the stairs."

[Navigation and Orienteering > Navigation by the Sun]
The sun rises roughly in the east and sets roughly in the west. At solar noon, the sun is due south in the Northern Hemisphere and due north in the Southern Hemisphere.

Shadow stick method: place a straight stick vertically in the ground. Mark the tip of its shadow. Wait 1520 minutes. Mark the new shadow tip. A line from the first mark to the second runs approximately west to east (first mark is west). A perpendicular line gives north-south.

Watch method (Northern Hemisphere): point the hour hand at the sun. The midpoint between the hour hand and 12 o'clock is approximately south. In the Southern Hemisphere, point 12 o'clock at the sun  the midpoint between 12 and the hour hand is approximately north. Use the watch at standard time, not daylight saving.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Navigation by Stars  Northern Hemisphere]
The North Star (Polaris) indicates true north. It sits within 1 of the celestial north pole. Find it by locating the Big Dipper (Ursa Major)  the two stars forming the front edge of the "cup" (Dubhe and Merak) point to Polaris. The distance to Polaris is approximately 5 times the distance between those two pointer stars.

If the Big Dipper is obscured, use Cassiopeia  a W-shaped constellation on the opposite side of Polaris from the Big Dipper. Polaris lies roughly between Cassiopeia and the Big Dipper.

Orion rises in the east and sets in the west. Orion's belt (three stars in a row) runs approximately east-west when rising or setting. Mintaka, the rightmost belt star, rises due east and sets due west.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Navigation by Stars  Southern Hemisphere]
There is no bright pole star in the southern sky. Use the Southern Cross (Crux) to find south. Extend the long axis of the Cross (from the top star through the bottom star) 4.5 times its length. That point is approximately the south celestial pole. Drop a vertical line from that point to the horizon  that's due south.

Alternatively, draw a line between the two Pointer Stars (Alpha and Beta Centauri). Find the midpoint. Draw a perpendicular line from that midpoint  it intersects with the extended line from the Southern Cross at the south celestial pole.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Navigation by Moon]
A crescent moon: draw an imaginary line through the two tips (horns) of the crescent down to the horizon. In the Northern Hemisphere, this point is approximately south. In the Southern Hemisphere, approximately north.

When the moon rises before sunset, the illuminated side faces west. When it rises after midnight, the illuminated side faces east.

A full moon is highest in the sky at midnight and is roughly opposite the sun  so at midnight a full moon is roughly due south (Northern Hemisphere) or due north (Southern Hemisphere).

[Navigation and Orienteering > Dead Reckoning]
When you can't see landmarks, navigate by dead reckoning: keep track of your direction (compass bearing) and distance traveled. Count paces to measure distance. Determine your pace count: walk 100 metres on flat ground and count double-paces (every time your left foot hits the ground). Most adults take 6070 double-paces per 100m. On rough terrain, add 1015%.

Record each leg of your journey: bearing, pace count, and any landmarks. This lets you retrace your route or plot your position on a map.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Handrails, Backstops, and Aiming Off]
A handrail is a linear feature you can follow  a river, ridge, fence line, power line, road. Use handrails to simplify navigation.

A backstop (or catching feature) is a large feature beyond your destination that tells you you've gone too far  a road, river, coastline, ridgeline.

Aiming off: when navigating to a point on a linear feature (eg. a bridge on a river), deliberately aim to one side. When you hit the river, you know which direction to turn to reach the bridge. This avoids the uncertainty of arriving at the feature and not knowing if your target is left or right.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Natural Navigation Signs]
Prevailing wind shapes trees  branches grow longer on the lee side. In the UK and much of the Northern Hemisphere, prevailing wind is from the southwest, so trees lean and have more growth on the northeast side.

Moss grows on the side of trees and rocks that gets the most moisture and least sun  often the north side in the Northern Hemisphere, but this is unreliable as a sole indicator. Use it to confirm other evidence, not as your primary method.

Spider webs are often built on the sheltered (south) side of objects.

Satellite dishes in Europe generally point roughly south-southeast (toward geostationary satellites over the equator). In the Southern Hemisphere they point roughly north.

Snow melts first on south-facing slopes (Northern Hemisphere). North-facing slopes retain snow longer.

Ant hills in Europe tend to be on the south side of trees (for warmth). The south side of the mound often has a gentler slope.

[Navigation and Orienteering > Distance Estimation]
At night, sounds carry further and seem closer than they are. In daytime, objects appear closer in clear air and further in haze.

Rules of thumb for visual estimation: a person is barely visible at 2 km. Individual windows visible at 1 km. Face detail visible at 100m. Eye detail visible at 50m.

Sound estimation: a shout carries approximately 1 km. A gunshot 35 km. Thunder: count seconds between flash and sound, divide by 3 for distance in kilometres (or divide by 5 for miles).

[Radio Communications > Radio Basics]
Radio waves are electromagnetic radiation. They travel at the speed of light and can be reflected, refracted, and absorbed. Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz). Higher frequencies carry more data but travel shorter distances and are blocked more easily by obstacles. Lower frequencies travel further and penetrate obstacles better but carry less data.

Key frequency bands:
- HF (High Frequency): 330 MHz. Long range via skywave propagation (bounces off the ionosphere). Can reach hundreds or thousands of kilometres. Best for long-distance communication when infrastructure is down.
- VHF (Very High Frequency): 30300 MHz. Line-of-sight plus some diffraction over hills. Range typically 1050 km on ground. Used for FM broadcast, marine radio, aviation, amateur radio (2m band at 144148 MHz).
- UHF (Ultra High Frequency): 300 MHz3 GHz. Strictly line-of-sight. Range typically 520 km on ground. Better building penetration than VHF. Used for PMR446 (walkie-talkies), amateur radio (70cm band at 430440 MHz), FRS/GMRS.

[Radio Communications > License-Free Radio Options]
PMR446 (Europe): 446 MHz UHF, 16 channels, 500mW power limit. No license required. Range 15 km depending on terrain. Widely available, inexpensive handheld radios. Good for local group communication.

FRS (USA/Canada): Family Radio Service, 462/467 MHz UHF. 22 channels, 2W power limit. No license required. Range 13 km typical.

GMRS (USA): General Mobile Radio Service. Shares frequencies with FRS but allows up to 50W and repeater use. Requires a license (no exam).

CB Radio: Citizens Band, 27 MHz (HF). 40 channels, 4W AM or 12W SSB. No license required in most countries. Range 515 km on ground, but can skip hundreds of kilometres via ionospheric propagation (especially during solar maximum). Bulkier antennas than UHF but good for vehicle-mounted use.

[Radio Communications > Amateur (Ham) Radio]
Amateur radio requires a license obtained by passing an exam. Licenses grant access to a wide range of frequencies from HF to microwave. In emergencies, most jurisdictions allow unlicensed use on amateur frequencies when life is at risk.

Key amateur bands for survival:
- 80m band (3.54 MHz): good for regional communication, especially at night (100500 km).
- 40m band (77.3 MHz): best all-round HF band, works day and night (1002000+ km).
- 20m band (1414.35 MHz): best for long-distance daytime communication (5005000+ km).
- 2m band (144148 MHz VHF): local communication. Many repeaters extend range. Standard for local emergency nets.
- 70cm band (430440 MHz UHF): similar to 2m but better for handheld use. Shorter range.

SSB (Single Sideband) is more efficient than AM for voice  use upper sideband (USB) on frequencies above 10 MHz, lower sideband (LSB) below 10 MHz. FM is used on VHF/UHF.

[Radio Communications > Emergency Frequencies]
International distress frequencies:
- 121.5 MHz: aviation emergency (VHF AM). Monitored by aircraft and search-and-rescue.
- 156.8 MHz (Channel 16): maritime distress (VHF FM). Monitored by coast guard and vessels.
- 2.182 MHz: maritime distress (HF). Monitored internationally.
- 406 MHz: emergency locator beacons (EPIRB, PLB, ELT). Satellite-detected.

Amateur emergency frequencies (calling frequencies):
- 7.110 MHz (40m): common HF emergency net.
- 14.300 MHz (20m): international emergency traffic.
- 145.500 MHz (2m FM): European calling/emergency.
- 146.520 MHz (2m FM): North American calling frequency.

Channel 9 on CB (27.065 MHz) is designated for emergencies in many countries.

[Radio Communications > Antenna Basics]
The antenna is the most important part of any radio system. A better antenna improves both transmission and reception far more than increasing transmitter power.

Dipole antenna: a wire cut to half the wavelength of your target frequency, split in the middle and fed with coax cable. Simple, effective, and can be made from any wire. For 7 MHz (40m band): total length approximately 20 metres (10m each side). Hang horizontally between trees for best results.

Quarter-wave vertical: a single wire or rod, one quarter of the wavelength, mounted vertically. Needs a ground plane (radial wires on the ground, or a vehicle roof). Good omnidirectional coverage.

Higher antennas perform better. Getting an antenna even a few metres above ground makes a significant difference, especially for VHF/UHF. Use trees, poles, buildings.
