Wire antennas can be improvised from any conductive wire  electrical wire, fence wire, even aluminium foil strips.

[Radio Communications > Repeaters]
VHF/UHF repeaters are automatic relay stations on hilltops or tall buildings. They receive on one frequency and retransmit on another, extending the range of handheld radios from a few kilometres to 50+ km. Most amateur repeaters use a standard offset (eg. +600 kHz on 2m). Some require a CTCSS tone (a sub-audible tone your radio transmits to activate the repeater). In a post-infrastructure scenario, solar-powered repeaters could provide critical regional communication.

[Radio Communications > Radio Procedure]
Standard voice procedure ensures clear communication:
- Identify yourself and the station you're calling: "Alpha Base, this is Foxtrot One."
- Wait for acknowledgment before transmitting your message.
- Keep transmissions brief and clear. Speak slowly and distinctly.
- Use the NATO phonetic alphabet for spelling: Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta, Echo, Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel, India, Juliet, Kilo, Lima, Mike, November, Oscar, Papa, Quebec, Romeo, Sierra, Tango, Uniform, Victor, Whiskey, X-ray, Yankee, Zulu.
- "Roger" = understood. "Wilco" = will comply. "Over" = I'm done speaking, awaiting reply. "Out" = conversation ended.
- "Mayday" (x3) for life-threatening emergencies. "Pan-Pan" (x3) for urgent but not life-threatening situations.
- Include your position (grid reference or description), the nature of the emergency, number of people involved, and assistance required.

[Radio Communications > Radio Discipline]
In a survival situation, minimise transmissions  every transmission reveals your position to anyone with a direction-finding antenna. Use low power when possible. Keep conversations short. Establish scheduled contact times (skeds) rather than transmitting continuously. Use code words for sensitive locations if operational security is a concern.

Batteries are the primary constraint for portable radio. A 5W VHF handheld typically runs 812 hours on a full battery with moderate use. Carry spares. Solar charging is viable for long-term operation.

[Radio Communications > Improvised Communication]
Signal mirror: a flat reflective surface aimed at an aircraft or distant person. Flash three times (SOS). Effective up to 50+ km in clear weather.

Smoke signals: three fires in a triangle is an international distress signal. Add green vegetation for white smoke (visible against dark backgrounds) or oil/rubber for black smoke (visible against light backgrounds).

Ground-to-air signals: lay out large symbols using logs, rocks, or fabric in open ground. V = require assistance. X = require medical help. I = require doctor.  = travelling in this direction. Standard size: at least 3 metres tall, 30cm wide lines.

Whistles carry further than shouting and require less energy. Three blasts is a universal distress signal.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Why Sanitation Matters]
More people throughout history have died from waterborne diseases and poor sanitation than from violence. Cholera, typhoid, dysentery, and hepatitis spread through faecal contamination of water. Establishing proper sanitation is one of the highest priorities for any settlement  it prevents epidemics that can decimate a community in days.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > The Faecal-Oral Route]
The primary disease transmission path: pathogens from faeces reach the mouth via contaminated water, unwashed hands, contaminated food, or flies. Breaking this chain at any point prevents disease. The key interventions: safe waste disposal, clean water, handwashing, food hygiene, and fly control.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Latrine Construction]
Cat hole (short-term): dig a hole 1520cm deep, at least 60m from water sources, trails, and camp. Bury waste and toilet paper. Adequate for individuals or small groups for a few days. Simple pit latrine: dig a pit at least 2m deep, 1m wide. Build a platform over it with a squat hole or seat. Surround with privacy walls. Place at least 30m from any water source and downhill from the water supply. A well-maintained pit latrine serves a family for 25 years. VIP latrine (Ventilated Improved Pit): as above but add a ventilation pipe (10cm diameter PVC or bamboo) from the pit extending above the roof, with a fly screen at the top. The pipe creates an updraft that vents odour and traps flies (they fly toward the light at the top of the pipe and cannot escape through the screen). Significantly reduces smell and fly problems. Composting toilet: separates urine and faeces. Faeces are mixed with carbon material (sawdust, dry leaves, wood ash) after each use. When the container is full, seal and compost for at least 12 months. The heat from composting kills pathogens. The finished compost is safe for fruit trees and non-food crops. Urine can

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Latrine Construction]
(sawdust, dry leaves, wood ash) after each use. When the container is full, seal and compost for at least 12 months. The heat from composting kills pathogens. The finished compost is safe for fruit trees and non-food crops. Urine can be diluted 10:1 with water and used as nitrogen fertiliser. Arborloo: a shallow pit latrine with a tree planted on top when full. Dig a new pit, move the superstructure. The tree grows vigorously from the nutrient-rich pit. An elegant long-term solution for settlements.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Handwashing]
Handwashing with soap reduces diarrhoeal disease by 4050%. It is the single most effective hygiene intervention. Wash hands: after using the latrine, before preparing food, before eating, after handling animals, after handling waste.

Tippy tap: a simple hands-free handwashing station. Hang a water container (jerry can with a small hole or a gourd) from a frame. A foot-operated lever tilts the container to pour water. Place soap on a string nearby. No-touch operation reduces cross-contamination.

Soap making: combine fat/oil (animal fat rendered to tallow, or plant oils) with lye (sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide). Lye from wood ash: pour water through hardwood ash (oak, hickory, beech) and collect the drippings (potassium carbonate solution). Concentrate by boiling. Mix lye solution with melted fat at approximately 40C, stir until it thickens (trace), pour into moulds. Cure for 46 weeks. The resulting soap is effective for cleaning and handwashing. Hot-process method: cook the mixture for 12 hours  soap is usable immediately.

If no soap is available: ash and water form a mild alkali solution that kills many pathogens. Sand can be used as an abrasive cleanser. Alcohol-based solutions (strong spirits) sanitise hands effectively.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Water Treatment]
All drinking water should be treated. See the Water domain for detailed methods. Key points: boil for 1 minute (3 minutes above 2000m), chemical treatment with bleach (2 drops per litre), SODIS (clear bottle in sun for 6 hours), or filtration through sand/charcoal followed by boiling.

Protect water sources: fence off springs and wells to prevent animal contamination. Designate separate areas upstream for drinking water collection and downstream for washing and bathing. Never defecate or dump waste near water sources.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Food Hygiene]
Wash hands before preparing food. Cook food thoroughly  internal temperature of 70C for at least 2 minutes kills most pathogens. Eat cooked food promptly  bacteria multiply rapidly at room temperature (doubling every 20 minutes in ideal conditions).

Separate raw and cooked food. Use different cutting surfaces and utensils for raw meat and ready-to-eat food. Wash all utensils with hot soapy water after use.

Protect food from flies  cover with cloth or mesh. Flies land on faeces and then on food, transferring pathogens directly. Fly control is food hygiene.

Store perishable food in the coolest available place. A zeer pot (evaporative cooler  a pot within a pot, wet sand between them) can reduce temperature by 1015C in dry climates. Root cellars maintain temperatures of 1015C year-round.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Waste Management]
Separate waste: organic waste (food scraps, plant matter)  compost. Burnables (paper, clean wood)  fuel. Metals, glass  salvage. Medical waste (bandages, sharps)  burn in a hot fire.

Compost: layer green waste (nitrogen-rich: food scraps, fresh plants) and brown waste (carbon-rich: dry leaves, straw, sawdust) in approximately equal volumes. Keep moist but not waterlogged. Turn every 12 weeks. A well-managed compost pile reaches 5565C, killing pathogens and weed seeds. Ready in 24 months.

Grey water (from washing): filter through a gravel/sand bed before releasing to the ground. Do not allow grey water to pool near living areas  it breeds mosquitoes. Irrigate trees or non-food crops with grey water.

Refuse pit: for non-compostable, non-burnable waste. Dig a pit at least 2m deep, away from living areas and water. Cover waste with soil regularly to prevent flies and odour. When full, cover with 60cm of soil.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Disease Prevention]
Diarrhoeal diseases: prevented by safe water, handwashing, and food hygiene. If outbreak occurs, isolate patients, enforce strict handwashing, boil all water, and identify/eliminate the contamination source.

Mosquito-borne diseases (malaria, dengue): eliminate standing water where mosquitoes breed  empty containers, fill puddles, cover water storage. Sleep under mosquito nets. Burn smoky fires in the evening. Wear long sleeves and trousers at dusk and dawn.

Respiratory infections: ventilate living spaces. Isolate sick individuals. Cover coughs and sneezes. Wash hands after contact with sick persons.

Wound infections: clean all wounds promptly with clean water and soap. See Medical domain for wound care. Keep wounds covered and dry. Change dressings regularly. Watch for signs of infection: increasing redness, swelling, warmth, pus, red streaks spreading from the wound, fever.

Rodent-borne diseases: store food in sealed containers. Keep living areas clean. Block entry points. Traps are safer than poison in a settlement. Do not handle dead rodents with bare hands.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Personal Hygiene]
Bathing: wash the body regularly, even if only with a cloth and water. Focus on groin, armpits, feet, and hands  areas where bacteria thrive. In cold water, a strip wash (washing sections at a time while keeping the rest clothed) prevents dangerous heat loss.

Dental hygiene: a frayed twig (miswak  from Salvadora persica, or any fibrous twig) works as a toothbrush. Baking soda mixed with water is an effective toothpaste. Salt water rinse kills bacteria. Dental infections can become life-threatening  prevention is critical.

Foot care: keep feet dry. Change socks daily. Treat blisters promptly  clean, drain if large (sterilised needle), cover with clean dressing. Foot rot and trench foot develop after prolonged exposure to wet conditions  dry and warm feet as soon as possible. Elevate feet when resting.

Clothing: wash clothes regularly, especially undergarments. Lice thrive in dirty clothing and spread typhus. Boiling clothing kills lice and their eggs. Ironing seams (where lice hide) is effective. If lice are detected, treat all clothing and bedding simultaneously.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Menstrual Hygiene]
Reusable cloth pads can be made from absorbent fabric (cotton, flannel). Fold into pad shape, secure with ties or a belt. Wash in cold water first (to remove blood), then hot soapy water. Dry in sunlight  UV helps sterilise. A menstrual cup (if available) is reusable for years and requires only boiling to sterilise between cycles.

[Sanitation and Hygiene > Quarantine Procedures]
If a contagious disease appears: isolate the patient in a separate shelter. Designate one or two caregivers who limit contact with the rest of the community. Caregivers wash hands thoroughly before and after contact. All bedding, clothing, and utensils used by the patient should be boiled or burned. Restrict movement in and out of the settlement until the outbreak is controlled.

[Shelter and Protection > Priorities]
The survival rule of threes: you can survive 3 minutes without air, 3 hours without shelter in extreme conditions, 3 days without water, 3 weeks without food. Shelter is often your most urgent need  hypothermia kills faster than dehydration or starvation.

[Shelter and Protection > Site Selection]
Choose a site that is: protected from wind, not in a flood plain or dry riverbed, away from dead trees (widowmakers), near water but not in a depression (cold air pools), on slightly elevated ground, near building materials. Avoid hilltops (wind exposure), valley floors (cold air sinks), and areas under lone tall trees (lightning risk).

[Shelter and Protection > Debris Hut]
The most important emergency shelter in temperate forests. Lay a ridgepole (3m long, sturdy branch) from the ground to a support (tree fork, rock) at about waist height. Lean branches against the ridgepole at 45 on both sides. Layer leaves, pine needles, bracken, or grass over the frame  minimum 60cm thick (the thicker the better). The shelter should be just big enough to fit inside  smaller spaces retain body heat. Fill the interior floor with dry leaves for insulation from the ground. A properly built debris hut can keep you warm in near-freezing conditions without a fire.

[Shelter and Protection > Lean-To]
Quick to build, good for moderate conditions. Lash a horizontal pole between two trees at about 1.5m height. Lean branches against it at 45 on one side. Cover with leaves, bark, or a tarp. Build your fire on the open side  the lean-to reflects heat back. Less insulated than a debris hut but allows fire use.

[Shelter and Protection > Tarp Shelter Configurations]
If you have a tarp or plastic sheet: A-frame (ridge line between two trees, tarp draped over), lean-to (one edge high, opposite staked low), or diamond (hung from centre point, corners staked out for 360 rain protection). Use 550 paracord or natural cordage. Always angle away from prevailing wind.

[Shelter and Protection > Snow Shelters]
Quinzhee: pile snow into a mound 2m high, let it sinter (harden) for 2-3 hours, then hollow out from one side. Wall thickness 30-40cm. Poke a ventilation hole near the top. Interior stays around 0C even when outside is much colder. Body heat warms the small space.

Snow trench: dig a trench in deep snow, lay branches or a tarp across the top, cover with snow. Quick and effective.

[Shelter and Protection > Insulation from the Ground]
The ground steals body heat via conduction faster than air via convection. Always insulate between you and the ground. Use: dry leaves (30cm thick minimum), pine boughs, grass bundles, bark, a sleeping pad, or even a pile of small branches. This is more important than insulation above you.

[Shelter and Protection > Cooling Shelter (Hot Climates)]
In desert or tropical heat: dig a shallow trench and cover with a raised shade structure (tarp, branches with leaves). Air circulates through the gap. The ground below surface level is cooler. Minimise physical activity during the hottest hours (10am-4pm). Rest in shade.

[Shelter and Protection > Improvised Cordage]
Natural cordage from: inner bark of dead trees (lime, willow, elm), long grasses twisted together, nettle stems (dried and processed), cattail leaves, or roots split lengthwise. Reverse-wrap technique: take two strands, twist each clockwise, then wrap them around each other counter-clockwise. Test strength before relying on it for shelter construction.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Finding Water]
In temperate climates, water collects in valleys, depressions, and at the base of hills. Follow animal tracks downhill  they often lead to water sources. Birds flying in a straight line at dawn or dusk are usually heading to water. Bees are never more than 5 km from water. Green vegetation in an otherwise dry area indicates underground water.

Dig in dry riverbeds at the outside of bends  water collects there even when the surface is dry. Dig to about 1 metre. In coastal areas, dig above the high tide line  freshwater floats on salt water.

Morning dew can be collected by tying absorbent cloth around your ankles and walking through grass before sunrise. Wring into a container. You can collect 500ml1L per hour this way.

Rainwater is generally safe to drink without treatment if collected directly.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Solar Still]
Dig a hole approximately 1 metre wide and 60cm deep. Place a container in the centre. Cover the hole with a clear plastic sheet, seal the edges with soil or rocks. Place a small stone in the centre of the sheet so it dips toward the container. Sunlight heats the ground, moisture evaporates and condenses on the underside of the plastic, drips into the container. Yields 500ml1L per day depending on soil moisture and sunlight. Add non-poisonous green vegetation to the hole to increase output.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Transpiration Bag]
Tie a clear plastic bag around a leafy branch of a non-poisonous tree. Sunlight causes the leaves to transpire  moisture collects in the bottom of the bag. Yields 200500ml per day per bag. Best with broadleaf trees. Set up multiple bags.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Boiling]
Boiling is the most reliable purification method. Bring water to a rolling boil for at least 1 minute. At elevations above 2000m, boil for 3 minutes due to the lower boiling point. Boiling kills bacteria, viruses, and parasites. Does not remove chemical contaminants.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Chemical Treatment]
Household bleach (5.25% sodium hypochlorite): add 2 drops per litre of clear water, 4 drops for cloudy water. Stir and wait 30 minutes before drinking.

Iodine tablets: follow manufacturer's instructions. Typically 1 tablet per litre, wait 30 minutes. Do not use long-term  excess iodine affects thyroid function. Not recommended for pregnant women.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Filtration]
In an emergency, filter through layers: gravel, then sand, then charcoal (from a fire, crushed). This removes particulates and some bacteria but does NOT make water safe alone  still boil after filtering.

Charcoal adsorbs some chemicals and improves taste. Activated charcoal is best but regular wood charcoal works in emergencies.

SODIS (Solar Disinfection): fill clear PET plastic bottles with water, place in direct sunlight for 6 hours (or 2 days in cloudy conditions). UV radiation kills pathogens. Bottles must be <2L for effective UV penetration.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Water Storage]
Store purified water in clean, sealed containers away from sunlight. Rotate every 6 months. Add 2 drops of bleach per litre for long-term storage.

A healthy adult needs 23 litres of water per day in temperate conditions. In hot conditions or during heavy physical activity, this rises to 46 litres. Dehydration symptoms: dark urine, headache, dizziness, dry mouth.

[Water Procurement and Purification > Signs of Contaminated Water]
Avoid water that has: a foul smell, oily film on the surface, green algae bloom, dead animals nearby, or is downstream from industrial or agricultural areas. Stagnant water is higher risk than flowing water.

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Barometric Pressure]
Atmospheric pressure is the single best indicator of short-term weather changes. Normal sea-level pressure is approximately 1013 hPa (millibars) or 29.92 inches of mercury.

Rising pressure generally indicates improving weather  clearing skies, less wind. Falling pressure indicates deteriorating weather  approaching storms, rain, increased wind. Rapidly falling pressure (more than 34 hPa in 3 hours) warns of severe weather approaching, potentially within hours.

Steady high pressure (above 1020 hPa) usually means fair weather. Steady low pressure (below 1000 hPa) means unsettled weather. The rate of change matters more than the absolute value.

If you have no barometer: observe water in a sealed glass jar with a spout  as pressure drops, water rises in the spout. A campfire's smoke rising straight up indicates high pressure; smoke beaten down and spreading along the ground indicates low pressure.

chunks.text:
[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Cloud Types and What They Mean]
Cirrus: thin, wispy, high-altitude (above 6000m). Made of ice crystals. Fair weather if sparse. If thickening and spreading, a warm front is approaching  rain in 1224 hours. Cirrostratus: thin, sheet-like veil at high altitude. Often creates a halo around the sun or moon. Warm front approaching  rain likely within 1224 hours. Cirrocumulus: small white puffs in rows at high altitude (mackerel sky). Indicates instability at high levels. Fair weather in the short term but change coming. Altocumulus: mid-level (20006000m) white or grey patches, often in waves or layers. If appearing on a warm, humid morning, thunderstorms may develop by afternoon. Altostratus: grey or blue-grey mid-level sheet. Sun appears as if through frosted glass. Continuous rain or snow approaching within hours. Stratocumulus: low, lumpy grey clouds in patches or sheets. Light rain or drizzle possible but often just overcast. Usually not severe. Stratus: uniform grey low-level layer, fog-like. Drizzle or light rain. Low visibility. Often burns off by midday. Cumulus: puffy, white, flat-bottomed clouds. Fair weather when small and widely spaced (cumulus humilis). If they grow tall during the day, becoming towering cumulus (cumulus congestus), thunderstorms may develop. Cumulonimbus: massive vertical development, anvil-shaped top. chunks.text:
[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Cloud Types and What They Mean]
Cumulus: puffy, white, flat-bottomed clouds. Fair weather when small and widely spaced (cumulus humilis). If they grow tall during the day, becoming towering cumulus (cumulus congestus), thunderstorms may develop. Cumulonimbus: massive vertical development, anvil-shaped top. Thunderstorms, heavy rain, hail, strong winds, possible tornadoes. The anvil shape indicates the cloud has reached the tropopause. Extremely dangerous  seek shelter immediately. Nimbostratus: thick, dark grey layer, obscures the sun completely. Continuous moderate to heavy rain or snow, lasting hours.

chunks.text:
[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Cloud Sequences]
Warm front approaching: cirrus  cirrostratus  altostratus  nimbostratus  rain. The whole sequence typically takes 1224 hours. Pressure falls steadily.

Cold front approaching: cumulus builds rapidly, sometimes preceded by a line of altocumulus. Cumulonimbus develops. Heavy rain, possibly with thunder, but passes quickly (13 hours). Sharp pressure drop then rapid rise. Temperature drops sharply after passage. Wind shifts clockwise (Northern Hemisphere).

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Wind and Weather]
Wind direction indicates where weather is coming from. In the Northern Hemisphere, stand with your back to the wind  low pressure is to your left (Buys Ballot's law). In the Southern Hemisphere, low pressure is to your right.

Increasing wind speed usually signals approaching weather systems. Sudden calm after strong winds can indicate the eye of a storm or a brief lull before a front passes.

Backing wind (shifting counter-clockwise, eg. south to east) indicates deteriorating weather. Veering wind (shifting clockwise, eg. south to west) indicates improving weather, often after a cold front passes.

Sea breezes blow onshore during the day (land heats faster than water), offshore at night (land cools faster). Mountain breezes blow downhill at night (cold air sinks), uphill during the day.

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Natural Weather Signs]
Red sky at night, shepherd's delight  a red sunset means clear skies to the west (where weather comes from in temperate zones). Red sky in the morning, shepherd's warning  a red sunrise means clear skies to the east (weather has already passed) and clouds approaching from the west. A halo around the sun or moon (caused by cirrostratus) means rain within 1224 hours. The ring is formed by ice crystals at high altitude. Dew on the grass in the morning indicates clear skies overnight and usually a fine day ahead. No dew suggests cloud cover overnight and possible rain. Frogs croak more loudly and persistently before rain. Their skin is sensitive to humidity changes. Swallows and swifts flying low indicates low pressure  insects are forced down by moisture-laden air. Birds flying high indicates fair weather. Pine cones close their scales when humidity rises (rain approaching) and open in dry weather. Distant sounds seem louder and clearer before rain  sound travels better through moist, dense air under low pressure. Smoke from a fire rising vertically indicates stable high pressure and fair weather. Smoke spreading horizontally or sinking indicates low pressure and approaching bad weather. Strong scent from

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Natural Weather Signs]
rain  sound travels better through moist, dense air under low pressure. Smoke from a fire rising vertically indicates stable high pressure and fair weather. Smoke spreading horizontally or sinking indicates low pressure and approaching bad weather. Strong scent from flowers and plants indicates high humidity and possible approaching rain  moist air carries scent molecules better.

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Fog]
Radiation fog forms on clear, calm nights when the ground cools rapidly. Common in valleys. Usually burns off by mid-morning. Indicates fair weather.

Advection fog forms when warm, moist air moves over a cold surface (eg. warm air over cold sea). Can persist for days.

Fog on hilltops that descends into valleys usually indicates deteriorating weather.

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Lightning Safety]
If the time between lightning and thunder is less than 30 seconds (the flash-to-bang is less than 10 km), seek shelter immediately. Avoid hilltops, open fields, isolated trees, water, and metal objects.

The 30-30 rule: if the time between flash and bang is 30 seconds or less, take shelter. Wait 30 minutes after the last flash before leaving shelter.

If caught in the open: crouch low (do not lie flat), feet together, hands on knees, minimise ground contact. Stay away from other people (spread out in a group). Drop metal objects.

[Weather Interpretation and Forecasting > Seasonal Patterns in Temperate Climates]
Spring: rapidly changing weather, alternating warm and cold fronts, frost risk until late spring. Thunderstorms develop as the ground warms.

Summer: longest days, warmest temperatures. Afternoon thunderstorms common in humid conditions. Heatwaves during blocking high-pressure systems.

Autumn: increasing storm frequency and intensity. First frosts. Fog becomes more common.

Winter: shortest days, coldest temperatures. Snow at elevation and in northern regions. Freezing rain, ice storms. Hypothermia risk highest.
